author: Katina Curtis
title: Federal Treasurer Joe Hockey vows crackdown on multinational tax dodgers | Business News | Business and Finance News | | The Advertiser
text:
THE Federal Government will initiate a crackdown on multinational tax dodgers within a month, Treasurer Joe Hockey says.
He has promised to put legislation to Parliament next month as a Senate committee prepares to release a report that is expected to call on the Government to name and shame those companies avoiding tax.
The Government will go after 30 primarily offshore-based companies that aren’t paying their fair share of tax, Mr Hockey told ABC radio.
It comes after BHP Billiton’s new chief commercial officer Dean Dalla Valle defended the group’s controversial Singapore marketing hub against accusations it was used to dodge tax in Australia.
In an exclusive interview with Business Daily today , Mr Dalla Valle said the customer needs, not tax rates, were the key factor determining where the mining titan based its market hub.
Mr Hockey said committee chair Labor senator Sam Dastyari had questions to answer about the release of recommendations to media outlets before the report had been signed off by other senators.
“It’s extraordinary,” Mr Hockey said. “This is a very serious issue that goes to the heart of the integrity of the entire Senate.”
Mr Hockey accused Senator Dastyari of trivialising the issue by playing political games.
Senator Dastyari denied speaking specifically about the unreleased report’s recommendations, insisting what he said were his personal views.
He argued there was a thirst for information within the community about what companies were up to.
“These companies do care about their reputations and they do care about their market share,” he told ABC TV.
“Exposing some of the worst practices, I believe, puts a lot more community pressure on these companies.”
Independent senator Nick Xenophon, who is also on the inquiry committee, said transparency was key.
“Whatever the government comes up with, the Senate will be in a much better position to consider that legislation given the forensic look we’ve had at this whole issue,” he told ABC radio.
Originally published as We’ll crack down on tax dodgers — Hockey
